*[Bug 18683] R 4.3.3 broken on < 10.10: error: property 'CGContext' not found on object of type 'NSGraphicsContext *'*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18683>

--- Comment #1 from Sergey Fedorov (<mailto:vital.had@gmail.com|vital.had@gmail.com>) ---
Judging from buildbots, 4.3.3 does build if `--without-aqua` is passed to
configure, however that is not an optimal solution, it is desirable to have a
fallback code, so that Cocoa support works.

P. S. Temporary fix:
<https://github.com/macports/macports-ports/pull/22876/commits/789842ecef8a9f7214809c9d448823e5fb219bad>
Build log from 10.6 (successful):
<https://build.macports.org/builders/ports-10.6_x86_64-builder/builds/191757/steps/install-port/logs/stdio>

*[Bug 18684] New: unexpected behavior from str()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18684>

            Bug ID: 18684
           Summary: unexpected behavior from str()
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.3.x
          Hardware: x86_64/x64/amd64 (64-bit)
                OS: Linux
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: minor
          Priority: P5
         Component: Low-level
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:dave.slager@gmail.com|dave.slager@gmail.com>

Note garbled order in first line of console output from str(). Is this a bug?

x_expected <- structure(quote(a > 2 * b))
str(x_expected)
#>  language a > 2 * b

x_unexpected <- structure(quote(a > 2 * b), class = 'new_class')
str(x_unexpected)
#>  language > a 2 * b
#>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "new_class"

text:
*[Bug 18684] unexpected behavior from str()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18684>

--- Comment #1 from Dave Slager (<mailto:dave.slager@gmail.com|dave.slager@gmail.com>) ---
Upon further investigation, this seems to arise from the behavior of the
internal as.vector function:

x_unexpected <- structure(quote(a > 2 * b), class = 'new_class')
str(x_unexpected)
#>  language > a 2 * b
#>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "new_class"

.Internal(as.vector(x_unexpected, 'character'))
#> [1] ">"     "a"     "2 * b"

elements.text:
) ---
Upon further investigation, this seems to arise from the behavior of the
internal as.vector function:

x_unexpected <- structure(quote(a > 2 * b), class = 'new_class')
str(x_unexpected)
#>  language > a 2 * b
#>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "new_class"

.Internal(as.vector(x_unexpected, 'character'))
#> [1] ">"     "a"     "2 * b"

text:
*[Bug 18685] New: dput(file = stderr()) warns "wrote too few characters" due to stderr_vfprintf() returning 0*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18685>

            Bug ID: 18685
           Summary: dput(file = stderr()) warns "wrote too few characters"
                    due to stderr_vfprintf() returning 0
           Product: R
           Version: R-devel (trunk)
          Hardware: All
                OS: All
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: minor
          Priority: P5
         Component: I/O
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:ikrylov@disroot.org|ikrylov@disroot.org>

Originally reported on
[R-help](<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-help/2024-March/479014.html>):

```
dput(letters, stderr())
# c("a", "b", "c", "d", "e", "f", "g", "h", "i", "j", "k", "l",
# "m", "n", "o", "p", "q", "r", "s", "t", "u", "v", "w", "x", "y",
# "z")
# Warning message:
# In dput(letters, stderr()) : wrote too few characters
```

This happens due to `Rconn_printf()` returning `0`, which is less than
`strlen(.)` for the line being printed.

Many connection types use `dummy_vfprintf()`, which reports the number of bytes
printed, and so does `file_vfprintf()`. Only `stderr_vfprintf()` and
`stdout_vfprintf()` return `0` unconditionally. `dput()` doesn't warn for `file
= stdout()` due to having a special case for connection number one.

text:
*[Bug 18683] R 4.3.3 broken on < 10.10: error: property 'CGContext' not found on object of type 'NSGraphicsContext *'*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18683>

Simon Urbanek (<mailto:simon.urbanek@r-project.org|simon.urbanek@r-project.org>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #3 from Simon Urbanek (<mailto:simon.urbanek@r-project.org|simon.urbanek@r-project.org>) ---
This is not a bug - OS X 10.10 is years out of support and outright dangerous
to run. Officially, we only support macOS 11 or higher while the aim is to not
unnecessary break compatibility for macOS 10.13 onward. Anything older you'll
have to either use old versions of R or patch the necessary compatibility.

You can expect more such issues the future since Apple has diverged quite a few
APIs and a lot of old APIs are deprecated so will have to be replaced with new
APIs sooner or later.

You can expect more such issues the future since Apple has diverged quite a few

APIs sooner or later.

text:
*[Bug 18683] R 4.3.3 broken on < 10.10: error: property 'CGContext' not found on object of type 'NSGraphicsContext *'*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18683>

--- Comment #4 from Sergey Fedorov (<mailto:vital.had@gmail.com|vital.had@gmail.com>) ---
(In reply to Simon Urbanek from comment #3)
Well, it is of course up to R developers to decide, but in most cases it is
trivial to keep a fallback code and avoid unnecessarily breaking something
which otherwise works perfectly fine.

Current R (well, at least 4.3.2) works on everything starting from 10.4
(Tiger). While 10.4 has issues with some dependents, on 10.5+ R ecosystem is
fully functional.
I regularly test R packages on 10.6 PowerPC, so I know it for the fact.

I would like to reiterate a request to keep older macOS in mind when making
breaking changes. I do not ask for any pro-active support for new features etc.
But whenever it is just a matter of retaining what works, maybe it is possible
to do that much? We know where API changes, so a single macro gonna fix it.

But whenever it is just a matter of retaining what works, maybe it is possible
